channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Battle Over Wage Rules for Tipped Workers Is Heating Up
item.description: A system counting tips toward the minimum wage is being fought in many places. Critics say it’s often abused. Defenders say workers benefit overall.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Base wages for tipped employees, who primarily work in the food and drinks service industry, remain low.

item.title: Germany Needs Coal to Replace Gas, So a Village Has to Go
item.description: The cutting of Russian gas supplies to Europe has led Germany to step up coal use, despite its goal to phase it out by 2030.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: An excavator working at the Garzweiler open-pit coal mine in Germany in August. The prospect of a winter without cheap Russian gas has dampened interest in greener policies.

item.title: Trump Aide Was Seen on Security Footage Moving Boxes at Mar-a-Lago
item.description: The aide, Walt Nauta, moved the boxes from a storage room before and after the Justice Department issued a subpoena demanding the return of all classified documents held by the former president.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department had subpoenaed security camera footage from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: House Jan. 6 Panel Plans a Sweeping Summation of Its Case Against Trump
item.description: In what may be its final public hearing, the committee intends to present new evidence about the former president’s state of mind and central role in the plan to overturn the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump speaking at a rally near the White House on Jan. 6, 2021, just before the Capitol riot.

item.title: With Leaps and Bounds, Parkour Athletes Turn Off the Lights in Paris
item.description: As an energy crisis looms, nimble young activists are using superhero-like moves to switch off wasteful lights that stores leave on all night.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Ha, 30, left, leader of the On The Spot Parkour collective in Paris, climbs a wall to turn off a shop’s exterior lights on the Avenue des Champs-Élysées, in September.

item.title: Can ‘Kinship Care’ Help the Child Welfare System? The White House Wants to Try.
item.description: The Biden administration proposes spending $20 billion over a decade to help some of the most vulnerable families in the country, including relatives suddenly thrust into child rearing.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Chet Strange for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Elena Thomas and her husband had to navigate the child welfare system when they took their grandchildren under their care.

item.title: Sandy Hook Families Win $1 Billion From Alex Jones
item.description: The Sandy Hook families leveraged personal stories, social media analysis and the Infowars fabulist’s lack of contrition to secure a major verdict.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones faces financial ruin after a jury awarded the families who had sued him almost $1 billion, though it is unclear how much money the families will ultimately collect.

item.title: In Utah, a Trump Loyalist Sends an S.O.S. to Romney, of All People
item.description: Senator Mike Lee, in a surprisingly close race for re-election, has antagonized Mitt Romney and the state’s G.O.P. for years. His plea now? “Please, get on board.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mike Lee played a key role in trying to help Donald J. Trump subvert the 2020 election, while his fellow Republican Utah senator, Mitt Romney, was in staunch opposition.

item.title: Enthusiasm for Trump Fluctuates Among Republicans on Campaign Trail
item.description: Trying to win over swing voters without alienating the party’s base, Republican contenders talk far differently about the former president on rally stages than they do in televised debates.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republican contenders across the country are trying to sway moderate and independent voters while not alienating the party’s base of Trump loyalists.

item.title: Hochul Hits the Road, Even if It Veers From the Campaign Trail
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is forgoing retail politics and instead relying on an aggressive ad strategy and staged events that highlight state investments.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has appeared with President Biden twice in the last two weeks, including on Thursday in the Hudson Valley.

item.title: The Nap Bishop Is Spreading the Good Word: Rest
item.description: Tricia Hersey, founder of the Nap Ministry, sees rest as a revolutionary way to push back on America’s obsession with productivity at all costs.
item.dc:creator: Melonyce McAfee
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tricia Hersey, a.k.a. the Nap Bishop, has been experimenting with the idea of rest as liberation for nearly a decade.

item.title: Nury Martinez Resigns From Los Angeles City Council
item.description: The former Council president, Nury Martinez, faced calls from state leaders and President Biden to leave office after making racist remarks on a recording that emerged on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Al Seib/Los Angeles Times via Getty Images
item.media:description: The former Los Angeles City Council president Nury Martinez during a news conference in Los Angeles last month. Ms. Martinez announced her resignation as a councilwoman on Wednesday.

item.title: We Are Suddenly Taking On China and Russia at the Same Time
item.description: A battle over computer chips could have more long-term global impact than the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

item.title: Ben Sasse Is Nothing if Not Thoughtful. Right?
item.description: With the junior senator from Nebraska set to become the president of the University of Florida, it’s a good moment to plow into his most recent book.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Elon Musk Has Some Bad Ideas for Mass Transit. We Have Solutions.
item.description: Innovation is important, but Elon Musk’s impractical transit inventions do nothing to help solve today’s problems.
item.dc:creator: Adam Kovacs and Adam Westbrook

item.title: The Jan. 6 Committee Has Been Almost Wholly Ineffective
item.description: It has set itself up as the defender of America’s democracy. It’s the wrong venue for such a mission.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Caldwell
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times

item.title: A Revealing Racist Rant in L.A.
item.description: America is getting less white. That doesn’t mean it’s becoming less racist.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

item.title: Hurricane Ian Proved Why Ron DeSantis’s Version of Climate Resilience Is a Disaster
item.description: As the sea level rises, the resilience projects Gov. Ron DeSantis touts will have to be replaced, made higher, built larger.
item.dc:creator: Craig Pittman
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: It’s Time to Accept That North Korea Has Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The threat of a Korean conflict is rising and the U.S. has few other cards to play.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Lewis
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; images by Nosyrevy and Komarov Vitaly, via Getty Images

item.title: Haiti Has Been a Plaything of Powerful Forces for Too Long
item.description: Haiti is in crisis. If the U.S. wants to help, it needs to stop meddling.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Richard Pierrin/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the resignation of Ariel Henry, Haiti’s acting prime minister, set fires in the streets of Port-au-Prince this month.

item.title: In the House, These National Security Democrats Face Political Peril
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joshua Roberts/Reuters
item.media:description: From left, Abigail Spanberger, Elissa Slotkin and Elaine Luria at the Capitol shortly after they were elected to Congress in 2018. They face tough re-election bids, while Mikie Sherrill, right, has a stronger hold on her seat.

item.title: The Young Women Who Make TikTok Weep
item.description: Songwriters who have found success on the app via emotional catharsis have expanded its range, and piqued the music industry’s interest.
item.media:credit: Jaime Molina for The New York Times

item.title: Winter Squash Every Which Way
item.description: As well as a how-to for making your own pumpkin spice blend.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Nik Sharma for The New York Times (Photography and Styling)

item.title: What Are Your Holiday Shopping Plans? We Want to Know.
item.description: Tell us about deals, budgets, wish lists and game plans for this holiday season, which promises to be challenging for retailers and customers alike.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise and Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Retailers have a lot riding on this year’s holiday season.

item.title: 2 Police Officers Are Killed in Connecticut Shooting
item.description: A third officer was seriously wounded in the shooting in Bristol, Conn., the state police announced early Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Andy Detwiler, Armless Farmer Who Became a YouTube Star, Dies at 52
item.description: After a childhood accident, he learned how to drive tractors and feed farm animals with his feet. Then he started a popular farming channel on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Inside the Global Effort to Keep Perfectly Good Food Out of the Dump
item.description: Around the world, lawmakers and entrepreneurs are taking steps to tackle two of humanity’s most pressing problems: hunger and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vue Vang collected donated food from a Trader Joe’s in Fresno, Calif., where, under a new law, grocery stores are required to donate “the maximum amount of edible food that would otherwise be disposed.”

item.title: Hoping to Carry a Gun in New Jersey? You Might Need Insurance First
item.description: Legislative leaders are promoting some of the strictest firearms rules in the country, a response to the Supreme Court ruling that overturned a New York law barring most people from carrying guns in public.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: Legislation expected to be introduced in New Jersey on Thursday would ban handguns from 25 categories of public spaces, including bars, beaches, stadiums and day care centers.

item.title: Health Panel Recommends Screening All Kids 8 and Up for Anxiety
item.description: To address the mental health crisis facing American youth, experts also said adolescents should be screened for depression.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: United States Preventive Services Task Force
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Can You Drink On Antidepressants? What Experts Say About Safety.
item.description: The internet is full of warnings about antidepressants and drinking. Here’s what mental health experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Can Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Improve Mental Health?
item.description: On social media, exercises that aim to “tone” one of our body’s longest nerves have been touted as a cure-all for anxiety and other psychological ailments. Here’s what the research says.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Chloe Cushman

item.title: How You Can Use Anticipation to Enjoy Life More
item.description: Looking forward to something can be almost as good as experiencing it.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns
item.media:credit: Jakov Jakovljevic

item.title: Virtual Reality Therapy Could Give Relief to Seniors
item.description: Some care facilities are giving older adults a way to visit their pasts to boost their well-being.
item.dc:creator: Matt Fuchs

item.title: ‘Almost Famous’ Heads to Broadway, Purple Aura Intact
item.description: Cameron Crowe adapted his Oscar-winning screenplay, about writing for Rolling Stone in the ’70s, preserving parts of the movie’s soundtrack and zingers (Don’t take drugs!) for the stage.
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.media:description: The musical-theater version of “Almost Famous” is “meant to capture the same thing as the movie,” Cameron Crowe said, “a personal story with music that you love.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
